title: webgl does not work on Fedora

sentences.text: I've been trying to test out webgl, but I can't seem to make it work on Fedora at all.
pretty much everything on the first page of google hits for "webgl test".
Please note: I have tried this on clean installs (fully updated) of:
When I attempt to load a webgl page, the page pops up a error notice that says:
I get this error with --enable-gl, but on the advice of kbr (on #chromium), I tried launching chromium-browser with --enable-webgl --in-process-webgl
When I launch chromium-browser with --enable-webgl --in-process-webgl, I
GraphicsContext3D: error opening libGL.so.1: libGL.so.1: cannot open shared object file: Permission denied
I've done builds as both shared and static, it does not seem to affect thus bug in any way.
None of the systems contain any binary-only crap (e.g. nvidia).
There are no selinux denials or alerts triggered.

To confirm that dlopening libGL.so.1 works on Fedora, I wrote a very very trivial test program which mirrors what chromium appears to be doing in  third_party/WebKit/WebKit/chromium/src/WebGraphicsContext3DDefaultImpl.cpp,
which is where that error message is coming from.
This test program is attached as dlopen-libGL-test.cpp.
When run on Fedora (12 & 13), this is the output:
Now, grepping through the source code, I count five places where it appears to dlopen libGL.so.1:
The code in app/gfx/gl/gl_context_linux.cc doesn't seem to ever bother running dlclose(), but I concede that it could be buried somewhere else.
The code in chrome/gpu/gpu_main.cc doesn't check for success there (which it should, and output dlerror() if it fails).
Also, I don't see a dlclose()
The code in media/tools/player_x11/gl_video_renderer.cc checks for success, but doesn't output dlerror() on failure, instead, it does:

The code in third_party/mesa/MesaLib/src/glx/x11/dri_common.c does proper error checking, with debugging that includes dlerror(), and a dlclose(), but as I don't see that error, I can only assume that this code path is either not being triggered or that it is properly dlopening libGL.so.1 here.
And lastly, the code which causes the error message,
has proper error checking, with debugging that includes dlerror(), and a dlclose (but only if the dlsym() calls fail).
I cede that dlclose() doesn't seem to be necessary for a successful dlopen(), or even for repetitive dlopen() calls.
I'm not sure why chromium needs to dlopen(libGL.so.1) five times, but I also admit to not being an expert on dynamic loading.
(No comment was entered for this change.)

I added printfs to all of the codepaths where dlopen(libGL.so.1) is called (for success and failure), and none of them trigger except for the one in third_party/WebKit/WebKit/chromium/src/WebGraphicsContext3DDefaultImpl.cpp.
that as least as far as webgl is concerned, that's the only one that matters.
This is also the exact thing for me on Fedora 13
FWIW, I've never had webgl work for my on my (Ubuntu, Linux) laptop.
I figured it  wasn't yet implemented so I haven't thought about it too hard.
It seems you've reduced the problem to that dlopen() failing:
GraphicsContext3D: error opening libGL.so.1: libGL.so.1: cannot open shared object file: Permission denied
The error is quite curious -- it sounds like it's successfully found some file, but  then is unable to open that file.
Perhaps you could try strace and see what file  it's attempting to open.
BTW, the reason for all of these dlopening hijinks is an ugly workaround.
Really  we'd just dynamically link against libGL like any other app.
// Some versions of NVIDIA's GL libGL.so include a broken version of   // dlopen/dlsym, and so linking it into chrome breaks it.
So we dynamically   // load it, and use glew to dynamically resolve symbols.
It would be interesting to see what error gets thrown on Ubuntu, if any.
Error that is thrown on Kubuntu 9.10 (5.0.343.0 (40484) Ubuntu):
GraphicsContext3D: error opening libGL.so.1: libGL.so.1: cannot open shared object  file: Permission denied
But if I run chromium with sudo, then it prints:
Well, at least that much is consistent.
dlopen should not require sudo, as my test case code (attached to this ticket) specifies.
First, --in-process-webgl is not recommended and will not be supported forever.
Best to do your testing with  just --enable-webgl.

Second, perhaps there is something wrong or missing in the code which disables the security sandbox when -- in-process-webgl is specified, which would lead to permission errors attempting to open libGL.so.1.
Well, for what it is worth, I don't get any error logging to the console without
--in-process-webgl, but webgl doesn't work (and the websites fail with the same error).
The logic about the security sandbox not being completely disabled with
--in-process-webgl makes sense, but if so, it just means that I'm back to square 1 on trying to debug this. I would appreciate any additional suggestions or tips.
I think we should change some of the DLOGs to LOGs in src/app/gfx/gl/gl_context_linux.cc .
Is it possible for you to build Chromium?
Getting set up to build isn't difficult.
It would make it easier to figure  out what's going on.
All of this testing has been done on builds of Chromium that I build myself.
I'm the packager for the "semi-official" version of the Fedora chromium RPMS.
I can apply any suggested patches or make any changes that you need for debugging.
Could you change all the DLOGs to LOGs in src/app/gfx/gl/gl_context_linux.cc and see whether you get any  errors reported around creation of the OpenGL context?
First test results (Fedora 12, i686, running in VM):
I don't have time to do anything more today, but I will test on my actual Fedora 13 x86_64 system tomorrow.
Could you post or attach the output of glxinfo tomorrow?
The Intel graphics chip is a red flag.
glxinfo claims pbuffer support but I suspect it isn't really there.
It turns out glxinfo doesn't provide all of the desired information.
Is there any way you can check out the Mesa  3D sources (see http://www.mesa3d.org/repository.html ) , cd to progs/xdemos and make and run pbinfo?
Also, a pixmap based initialization path was just added within the last couple of days.
If it isn't already in your  app/gfx/gl/gl_context_linux.cc , could you sync to top of tree, rebuild, modify the DLOGs again and see what the  results are after the glXChooseFBConfig fails?
Attached is the output from pbinfo on my Fedora 13 x86_64 system.
With 6.0.412.0 (svn47812) on my Fedora 13 x86_64 laptop, this is the result:
WebGL enabled test pages don't throw the "No WebGL Context found" error anymore, but they're definitely not working at all.
Could you apply the attached patch to gl_context_linux.cc and see whether it improves the behavior?
Patch applied, does not change behavior.
Webgl apps still do not run, console output is:
The following revision refers to this bug:
Changed DLOG to LOG in gl_context_linux.cc to get informative error messages even in release builds when WebGL initialization fails.
I started trying to simplify this issue, and I found that both glxpbdemo and pbdemo (from mesa/progs/xdemos) were both crashing with the same error.
found that the issue had been opened upstream, and a patch written:
Sure enough, with that patch applied, glxpbdemo and pbdemo started working properly and chromium stopped throwing that error (or any error).
Unfortunately, webgl apps still aren't working for me, nothing gets drawn on the screen.
, and some of those tests seem to succeed, but the browser tab eventually "oh snap!"'s.
I would like to help debugging this, please advise.
Following up on my own query, I've finally found some webgl demos that work!
shiny-teapot did not work (teapot per vertex and teapot per pixel draw a black box, but nothing shows up in them).
Many Planets Deep worked on the second try (first try was our old friend "no WebGL context found")
Chocolux claims to work, but i don't think it is rendering properly, as it looks like a flat brown box (although, the fps is going up and down as if it is running).
I'm glad that things are beginning to work on your distribution.
It sounds like the remaining issues may be graphics driver bugs.
If you can dig deeper into the failures of some of  the demos, starting with the simpler ones, we can try to figure out whether there are workarounds possible in the  WebGL implementation.
I would like to close this bug;
do you have any concerns about my doing so?
No issue with closing this bug, as it is not a chromium issue.
I would however appreciate any documentation or advice on how to dig deeper into the failures of the demos, along with any explicit suggestions on which demos are "simpler ones".
The demos in the demo repository are simple ones to start debugging.
http://www.khronos.org/webgl/wiki/Demo_Repository has instructions on how to check out the demos on  your local machine.
Note that running these within Chromium off your local disk requires --allow-file-access- from-files on the command line (not recommended for general browsing however).
Open the JavaScript error console and look for anything printed there.
Also look at  http://khronos.org/webgl/wiki/Debugging for how to see any OpenGL errors generated by the application.
Closing as WontFix as the Chromium code appears to be working as intended.
